awd_titl_txt: Hybrid Multiscale Methods with Applications in Biomaterials and Bioengineering
awd_abstract_narration:
On the research side, this project aims to develop experimentally guided, hybrid multiscale models and methods to study complex biological systems and problems arising in biomaterials and bioengineering (a) sprouting angiogenesis during vascularization; (b) bacterial swarming during biofilm formation. This research will have many benefits to multiscale problems and relevant applications in biomaterials, tissue regeneration and biomedical engineering, which include bioprinting technology for fabricating tissues and organs, study of cell motions, drug design and ultimately regenerative medicine. These methods can be used as hypothesis generating and testing tools for biologists and bioengineers. Through collaboration with experimentalists, the PI will develop a hybrid multiscale approach to better understand complex mechanisms in the vascularization and the biofilm growth.  On the educational side, this project will not only provide multidisciplinary research training to graduate and undergraduate students, but also promote awareness and interest in computational mathematics and mathematical biology among underrepresented minority groups.


For the thrust (a), motivated by new findings in sprouting angiogenesis in bioprinting technology, the PI will integrate models for angiogenic signaling pathways with that for the mechanical motion. In particular, we employ typically coarse-grained continuum models (reaction-diffusion (RD) systems) to describe the dynamics of vascular-endothelial-growth-factor (VEGF) and nutrients/oxygen, a mechanical model for the extra-cellular matrix (ECM) based on the finite element method (FEM), and couple a discrete multicellular lattice model based on the kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) algorithm to describe the cellular dynamics. Communication between the microscale model and the continuum ones is carried out via a suite of multiscale protocols. For the thrust (b), the PI will study several mechanisms responsible for bacterial swarming during biofilm formation, such as bacterial chemotaxis, interaction between bacteria, bacterial shapes, etc. In the proposed hybrid agent-based model, bacteria are characterized by self-propelled particles (SPP) or self-propelled rods (SPR) and the dynamics of extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) in the environment is described by continuously changing fields. The multiscale model is described by a system of ordinary and partial differential equations. The research outcomes consist of a set of hybrid multiscale models, detailed implementation of the models, and accompanying in silico analysis tools for simulating tissue formation and ultimately 3D biofabrication involving angiogenesis and vascularization. The tools can provide efficient ways to systematically test the influence of individual cellular features under a spectrum of environmental conditions and to study the collective behavior of bacterial colonies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
With support from NSF grant #1913146, we have conducted research focused on developing new hybrid multiscale computational methods and algorithms to address problems in biomaterials and bioengineering.

From both theoretical and computational perspectives, the major outcomes of the project include new hybrid computational algorithms and their applications in simulating (a) sprouting angiogenesis during vascularization in cutting-edge bioprinting technology, and (b) bacterial swarming during biofilm formation. Specifically, in (a), a special agent-based model describes cell dynamics using a lattice model based on the kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) algorithm, while Reaction-diffusion (RD) systems are used to model the spatio-temporal variation of the concentrations of angiogenesis signaling molecules. In (b), we use the Vicsek swarming model to describe the dynamics of individual bacteria and employ partial differential equations (PDEs) to model the macroscale dynamics at the continuum level. The outcomes of our project also provide new insights that help us (a) understand how new blood vessels sprout from existing ones during vascularization, and (b) comprehend the mechanisms of bacterial motility and the factors influencing swarming, such as bacterial chemotaxis, interactions between bacteria, and bacterial shapes. However, we note that due to the impacts of COVID-19, our collaboration with experimentalists was significantly disrupted. As a result, we extended our agent-based lattice model with the KMC algorithm into an additional project (c). We developed an efficient list-based KMC method to study traffic and pedestrian flow models on one- and two-dimensional lattices. The numerical results align very well with the corresponding empirical results from real traffic. All these outcomes demonstrate the intellectual merits of our research.

 On the experimental side, we maintained close contact with experimentalists from Clemson and MUSC before the COVID-19 outbreak. Our work on projects (a) and (b) should interest those in biomaterials, tissue engineering, and cell biology. Our work on project (c) has also attracted researchers from the fields of traffic and civil engineering. On the educational side, our project has provided excellent opportunities for graduate students to receive simulation-based interdisciplinary research training. I am currently advising a Ph.D. student who is being trained in the interdisciplinary areas of applied and computational mathematics, bioengineering, and pedestrian engineering. I also mentored two undergraduate students, both of whom have conducted research on neuronal dynamics. Since 2020, I have been participating in a joint team between USC and Benedict College (an HBCU in SC) with expertise in computational mathematics, statistics, and engineering to develop curriculum, programs, and a workforce development pipeline. These efforts help to promote applied and computational mathematics among minorities and underrepresented groups. All these aspects reflect the broader impact of this project.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Yi Sun
